A useful thought experiment for deciding whether these criteria are valid or arbitrary, is by imagining that another alien species, who have a level of intelligence, self-awareness, rationality and reasoning that humans cannot even comprehend, dominated Earth. They understand us in the same way that we understand animals.

→ The Genetic Criterion: They could assert that entities without their alien make-up do not deserve moral consideration. Humans would not be included, that criterion would be immoral.

→ The Cognitive Criterion: They could assert that entities without certain properties that they possess do not deserve moral consideration. Humans would not be included, that criterion would be immoral.

→ The Social Criterion: They could assert that entities that none of them care about, or entities that are not recognised as deserving of moral consideration, should not be given moral consideration. None of those people have their personhood forfeited. Actually, now that I think about it, it is BECAUSE they are people that violence against them is justified. If they are deserving of our moral consideration, then they are also deserving of our moral condemnation. My personal belief is that the personhood of an object is partially or even entirely irrelevant as to whether or not that object deserves our moral consideration. Sentient objects in their entirety deserve moral consideration, though in degrees proportionate to the moral consideration they're prepared to give other objects worth considering. I see morality as an active system kept working by its participants, where those who do the most to help maintain it - or at the very least do the least to break it down - deserve to benefit from it the most. I don't see morality as capable of delivering "punishment," however, merely withdrawing "support" whereupon dire consequences may or may not happen.

Non-sentient objects can be worth our moral consideration, as well. Objects to which sentient beings have attributed meaning beyond their pure physical properties (a bible, the sphynx, your child's favourite teddy bear) do get to benefit from our system of morality, though I'd argue to a lesser extent. I do agree that moral consideration is not binary and some objects deserve more of it than others. Exactly where the balance falls is to be determined on a case-by-case basis, but I'd definitely include inanimate objects into morality as their own, separate entity.

Semi-sentient objects such as clearly intelligent but not fully sentient life forms (including toddlers) do deserve some amount of moral consideration, though again - to a lesser extent than fully-sentient beings. Yes, your one-year-old deserves more moral consideration than your cat, but that's by proxy of the baby having the potential to grow into a fully-sentient being while your cat does not. Anything with the potential to be fully sentient simply requires more care when dealing with it because of the agency it will one day be capable of wielding. Semi-sentient animals and inanimate objects don't have agency of their own, but fully sentient beings do, thus they get more moral consideration, both in terms of what they're allowed to do and what they're expected to do.

Basically, an object needs to have some degree of either sentience or importance ascribed to it by sentient beings in order to be worth considering morally. Fully sentient beings deserve the most consideration in general, but case-by-case basis exceptions do apply. Fully-sentient beings are also the only ones ascribed a moral responsibility along with their moral rights. Semi-sentient animals and inanimate objects only have rights, never responsibilities beyond the purely practical ones. You can't expect your cat to have sympathy for the poor because it lacks the capacity to comprehend that notion, thus you don't judge it if it demands food even when you can't afford it - that's just what it's capable of. It's your responsibility as a fully-sentient being to care for the cat and steer it away from causing trouble or - failing that - assign it to someone else who can.

Basically, sentience begets morality, but extenuating circumstances may apply. A blanket rule is unhelpful here.
